lines: A close friend of yours has taken on a peculiar habit lately. After every meal, she runs into the bathroom and throws up so that she doesn't have to worry about her weight. She doesn't seem to think there is anything weird about it,

She denies that she has any problem.
You convince yourself that you tried your best, but she wouldn't accept your help.
She gets angry at you and calls you names.

Your concern for your friend is admirable. It shows that you are sensitive to the amount of danger that she is in. Unfortunately, there is no way to help people like this. If she ever chooses to get straightened out, it will have to come

It often happens that when someone we care about is having serious problems, we ignore them, hoping that they will either vanish, or imagine that we never saw them in the first place. This is probably what your friend's parents have
done to her all her life. That's probably one of the reasons she is in such sad shape right now.

Perhaps you are angry because you are afraid that this person will embarrass you by having a problem. Sometimes when our friends have difficulties, we admonish ourselves for not being powerful enough to prevent or stop the problem.
Your anger only generates depression in your friend. As a result, everything you do for her fails, giving her more reasons to alter her body in a way that will make her seem more acceptable.

Perhaps you are upset because you think her behavior will be a negative reflection on you. Maybe you think that you should be or could be powerful enough to prevent her from further hurting herself. Both of your choices do
her no good at all. They only cause you to sit there shaking your head, saying, "How can she do this to herself?"
I guess this person really wasn't much of a friend. Either that, or you are so self-absorbed that you can't be bothered caring about anyone else.
